column1: What is COVID-19
column2: COVID-19 is the infectious disease caused by the most recently discovered coronavirus. This new virus and disease were unknown before the outbreak began in Wuhan, China, in December 201

column1: What are the symptoms of COVID-19
column2: The most common symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, tiredness, and dry cough. Some patients may have aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat or diarrhea. These symptoms are usually mild and begin gradually. Some people become infected but don¡¯t develop any symptoms and don't feel unwell.

column1: How does COVID-19 spread
column2: People can catch COVID-19 from others who have the virus. The disease can spread from person to person through small droplets from the nose or mouth which are spread when a person with COVID-19 coughs or exhales. These droplets land on objects and surfaces around the person. Other people then catch COVID-19 by touching these objects or surfaces, then touching their eyes, nose or mouth. People can also catch COVID-19 if they breathe in droplets from a person with COVID-19 who coughs out or exhales droplets.

column1: Can the virus that causes COVID-19 be transmitted through the air
column2: Studies to date suggest that the virus that causes COVID-19 is mainly transmitted through contact with respiratory droplets rather than through the air.

column1: Can CoVID-19 be caught from a person who has no symptoms
column2: The risk of catching COVID-19 from someone with no symptoms at all is very low.?

column1: What can I do to protect myself and prevent the spread of disease
column2: Regularly and thoroughly clean your hands with an alcohol-based hand rub or wash them with soap and water. Maintain at least 3 feet distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing.

column1: Should I wear a mask to protect myself
column2: People with no respiratory symptoms, such as cough, do not need to wear a medical mask. WHO recommends the use of masks for people who have symptoms of COVID-19 and for those caring for individuals who have symptoms, such as cough and fever.

column1: How to put on, use, take off and dispose of a mask
column2: Before touching the mask, clean hands with an alcohol-based hand rub or soap and water. Take the mask and inspect it for tears or holes. Orient which side is the top side (where the metal strip is). Ensure the proper side of the mask faces outwards (the colored side). Place the mask to your face. Pinch the metal strip or stiff edge of the mask so it molds to the shape of your nose. Pull down the mask¡¯s bottom so it covers your mouth and your chin.

column1: How likely am I to catch COVID-19
column2: The risk depends on where you live or where you have travelled recently. The risk of infection is higher in areas where a number people have been diagnosed with COVID-19.?

column1: Should I worry about COVID-19?
column2: If you are not in an area where COVID-19 is spreading, or if you have not travelled from one of those areas or have not been in close contact with someone who has and is feeling unwell, your chances of getting it are currently low.

column1: Who is at risk of developing severe illness
column2: While we are still learning about how COVID-2019 affects people, older persons and persons with pre-existing medical conditions (such as high blood pressure, heart disease, or diabetes) appear to develop serious illness more often than others.

column1: Are antibiotics effective in preventing or treating the COVID-19
column2: No. Antibiotics do not work against viruses, they only work on bacterial infections. COVID-19 is caused by a virus, so antibiotics do not work.

column1: How long is the incubation period for COVID-19
column2: Most estimates of the incubation period for COVID-19 range from 1-14 days, most commonly around five days.

column1: How long does the virus survive on surfaces
column2: It is not certain how long the virus that causes COVID-19 survives on surfaces, but it seems to behave like other coronaviruses. Studies suggest that coronaviruses (including preliminary information on the COVID-19 virus) may persist on surfaces for a few hours or up to several days.

column1: Is it safe to receive a package from any area where COVID-19 has been reported
column2: Yes. The likelihood of an infected person contaminating commercial goods is low and the risk of catching the virus that causes COVID-19 from a package that has been moved, travelled, and exposed to different conditions and temperature is also low.

column1: Is there a vaccine, drug or treatment for COVID-19
column2: Not yet. To date, there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat COVID-2019.

column1: How do I know if it is COVID-19 or just the common flu
column2: A COVID-19 infection has the same signs and symptoms as the common cold and you can only differentiate them through laboratory testing to determine the virus type.

column1: Can the virus that causes COVID-19 be transmitted through the air
column2: Studies to date suggest that the virus that causes COVID-19 is mainly transmitted through contact with respiratory droplets rather than through the air.

column1: What can I do to protect myself and prevent the spread of disease
column2: Stay aware of the latest information on the COVID-19 outbreak, available on the WHO website and through your national and local public health authority.

column1: I am well and asymptomatic. Should I use a mask
column2: According to the WHO, for individuals without respiratory symptoms, a medical mask is not required, as no evidence is available on its usefulness to protect non-sick persons.

column1: How likely am I to catch COVID-19
column2: The risk depends on where you are - and more specifically, whether there is a COVID-19 outbreak unfolding there.

column1: Are pregnant women more susceptible to the COVID-19 virus and will it harm the fetus
column2: We do not have information from published scientific reports about the susceptibility of pregnant women to COVID-19. Pregnant women experience immunologic and physiologic changes, which might make them more susceptible to viral respiratory infections, including COVID-19.

column1: What is the risk of my child becoming sick with COVID-19
column2: Based on available evidence, children do not appear to be at higher risk for COVID-19 than adults.

column1: Are the symptoms of COVID-19 different in children than in adults
column2: No. The symptoms of COVID-19 are similar in children and adults. However, children with confirmed COVID-19 have generally presented with mild symptoms.

column1: Should I worry about COVID-19
column2: Illness due to COVID-19 infection is generally mild, especially for children and young adults. However, it can cause serious illness: about 1 in every 5 people who catch it need hospital care. It is therefore quite normal for people to worry about how the COVID-19 outbreak will affect them and their loved ones.

column1: Who is at risk of developing severe illness
column2: While we are still learning about how COVID-2019 affects people, older persons and persons with pre-existing medical conditions (such as high blood pressure, heart disease, lung disease, cancer or diabetes) appear to develop serious illness more often than others.

column1: Are there any medicines or therapies that can prevent or cure COVID-19
column2: While some western, traditional or home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease. WHO does not recommend self-medication with any medicines, including antibiotics, as a prevention or cure for COVID-19.

column1: Is there a vaccine, drug or treatment for COVID-19
column2: Not yet. To date, there is no vaccine and no specific antiviral medicine to prevent or treat COVID-2019.

column1: Should I wear a mask to protect myself from catching the COVID-19 virus
column2: Only wear a mask if you are ill with COVID-19 symptoms (especially coughing) or looking after someone who may have COVID-19.

column1: Until when should I wear a mask after recovering from an illness with respiratory symptoms
column2: In order to avoid infecting others, you should use a mask for as long as you are still coughing or sneezing. You should only stop after a complete recovery (which means 24-48 hours after having no symptoms without medication).

column1: How long is the incubation period for COVID-19
column2: Most estimates of the incubation period for COVID-19 range from 1- 14 days, most commonly around five days.

column1: Can humans become infected with the COVID-19 from an animal source
column2: Possible animal sources of COVID-19 have not yet been confirmed.

column1: How long does the virus survive on surfaces
column2: Studies suggest that coronaviruses (including preliminary information on the COVID-19 virus) may persist on surfaces for a few hours or up to several days. This may vary under different conditions (e.g. type of surface, temperature or humidity of the environment).

column1: How can I get tested for COVID-19
column2: Call your local UN clinic/medical facility to inform them of your condition and relevant travel/exposure history. If you had been identified as a close contact of a case by the local Ministry of Health or WHO, please also indicate this. From here you will be advised if a medical assessment is necessary and how to get tested.

column1: What alternatives do I have if there are no hand sanitizers available
column2: If hand sanitizers are not available, hand washing with soap and water is the recommended, and even better, alternative.

column1: Can people who recover from COVID-19 be infected again
column2: We know that for similar coronaviruses, infected people are unlikely to be re-infected shortly after they recover. However, because the immune response to COVID-19 is not yet understood, it is not yet known whether similar immune protection will be observed for patients who have recovered from COVID-19.

column1: Is it safe to receive a package from an area where COVID-19 has been reported
column2: Yes. The likelihood of an infected person contaminating commercial goods is low and the risk of catching the virus that causes COVID-19 from a package that has been moved, travelled, and exposed to different conditions and temperature is also low.

column1: Is there a connection between COVID -19 and environment temperature
column2: It is not known yet if weather and temperature changes impact or has any connection with COVID-19. At this time, it is not clear or known if the spread of COVID-19 will decrease when the weather becomes warmer.

column1: Can I catch the virus from being in an enclosed space (i.e. bus, subway) in close proximity to someone who doesn¡¯t have respiratory symptoms
column2: Since the virus is transmitted through respiratory droplets, the risk of catching it from somebody who is asymptomatic, even a contact of a confirmed COVID-19 case, is low.

column1: Should I start avoiding people of Asian descent and their businesses
column2: The virus can affect anyone regardless of nationality, race and color. The Organization will not tolerate discrimination and encourages everyone to promote culturally appropriate and empathetic community engagement and to detect and rapidly respond to negative public perceptions and counter misinformation.

column1: When should we identify ourselves as "being sick" and stay at home
column2: Although a fever is a sure sign that you are sick enough not to come to work, anyone experiencing respiratory symptoms like coughing and sneezing should stay at home.

column1: Should I get a face mask
column2: CDC recommends wearing cloth face coverings?in public settings where other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain (for example, grocery stores and pharmacies) especially in areas of significant community-based transmission.

column1: Can I make my own hand sanitizer
column2: There are no studies supporting the effectiveness of homemade hand sanitizer blend in killing the new coronavirus on people¡¯s hands.

column1: Can coronavirus live on objects
column2: Although the new coronavirus weakens and dies over time outside of the human body, studies suggest that it can live on surfaces for a few hours or up to several days, depending on surface, temperature and other environmental factors.

column1: Is it safe to order take-out
column2: According to the?Food and Drug Administration (FDA),?there have not been any cases of COVID-19 known to be caused from eating food or handling food packaging.

column1: Is grocery shopping safe during the coronavirus pandemic
column2: It¡¯s best not to make unnecessary trips, but if you need to go to a grocery store, it¡¯s important to maintain social and physical distancing as you shop, and to clean your hands often while shopping and as soon as you get home.

column1: Should I stop going to the gym
column2: As the new coronavirus is spreading, be cautious about all possible exposures, including at the gym or fitness center. The virus isn¡¯t spread through perspiration (sweat), but items touched by many people (barbells, etc.) could pose a risk.

column1: Should I cancel my trip
column2: At this time,?social and physical distancing?are important to follow, so overall, travel is discouraged.

column1: Can humans get coronavirus from dogs or cats
column2: Despite the very few reports worldwide, including here in the United States, of sick and healthy domestic animals, including pets, testing positive for SARS-CoV-2, the official name for the virus that causes COVID-19, there is little evidence at this time that such animals are easily infected with the virus under normal conditions, or could transmit it.

column1: What is coronavirus fatality rate
column2: Right now, it appears that COVID-19, the disease caused by the new coronavirus, causes more cases of severe disease and more deaths than the seasonal flu. People over age 85 have the highest risk of fatality and children under 19, the lowest, but this could change as more people are tested and trends become clearer.?

column1: Can coronavirus live in heat
column2: Several countries currently affected by the new coronavirus outbreak are experiencing summer weather.

column1: Why is it called a ¡°coronavirus¡±
column2: Corona means ¡°crown,¡± and coronaviruses have a ¡°crown¡± of protruding points on their surface that give them a characteristic appearance when seen under a microscope. Coronaviruses are a whole family of viruses; there are many.

column1: What¡¯s the difference between the new coronavirus and other coronaviruses
column2: The new coronavirus is different from these, and was only identified in December 2019.

column1: What is 2019 Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19)
column2: COVID-19 is a new disease, caused by a novel (or new) coronavirus not previously seen in humans.

column1: What is the source of the virus
column2: Early on, many of the patients at the epicenter of the COVID-19 outbreak in China had some link to a large seafood and live animal market, suggesting animal-to-person spread.

column1: What does it mean that COVID-19 is a Global Pandemic
column2: A pandemic is a global outbreak of disease. Pandemics happen when a new virus emerges to infect people and can spread between people.

column1: What are the symptoms of COVID-2019
column2: People who are infected with COVID-19 have developed mild to severe respiratory illness with symptoms including fever, cough, shortness of breath, and potentially respiratory distress 2-14 days after exposure.

column1: How does COVID-19 spread
column2: Human coronaviruses typically spread through the air by coughing and sneezing.

column1: How is COVID-19 diagnosed
column2: There are many tests being used to diagnose COVID-19 that the U.S. Food & Drug Administration (FDA) has authorized for use during the current emergency. All of these diagnostic tests identify the virus in samples from the respiratory system, such as from nasal or nasopharyngeal swabs

column1: Can someone spread the virus without being sick
column2: Some spread might be possible before people show symptoms.?

column1: What does the Governor¡¯s stay at home order mean
column2: A stay at home order directs Illinoisans to stop movements outside of their homes beyond essential needs. By limiting social interactions, the chance of spreading COVID-19 is greatly reduced.

column1: What is social distancing
column2: Social distancing is deliberately increasing the physical space between people to avoid spreading illness.

column1: Can I go outdoors
column2: Yes, go outdoors for fresh air and exercise. Ride a bike, walk the dog, go for a hike, jog. Social distancing does not mean staying indoors, it means avoiding close contact with people.

column1: Can I go to the supermarket
column2: Yes. Buy as much as you need to lessen the number of trips and try and shop when the store is least likely to be crowded.

column1: Should I wear a facemask
column2: Cover your mouth and nose with a cloth face cover when around others.

column1: What steps should parents take to protect children
column2: Discourage children and teens from gathering in other public places while school is dismissed to help slow the spread of COVID-19 in the community. Encourage frequent handwashing and follow other prevention tips.

column1: Who is at higher risk
column2: Older adults and people of any age who have serious underlying medical conditions may be at higher risk for more serious complications from COVID-19.

column1: Should I clean ¡°high touch¡± surfaces
column2: Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces, such as tables, doorknobs, light switches, countertops, handles, desks, phones, keyboards, toilets, faucets and sinks.?

column1: Is there a vaccine
column2: No. Currently, there is not a vaccine for COVID-19.

column1: What are the treatments for COVID-19
column2: Currently, there are no specific treatments recommended for illnesses caused by COVID-19. Medical care is supportive to help relieve symptoms.

column1: Can I get COVID-19 from my pet
column2: Currently, there is no evidence that animals play a significant role in spreading the virus that causes COVID-19. Based on the limited information available to date, the risk of animals spreading COVID-19 to people is considered to be low.?

column1: Can animals carry the virus that causes COVID-19 on their skin or fur
column2: Although we know certain bacteria and fungi can be carried on fur and hair, there is no evidence that viruses, including the virus that causes COVID-19, can spread to people from the skin, fur, or hair of pets.

column1: What should health care providers, laboratories and health departments do
column2: Health care providers and laboratories should report suspect COVID-19 cases immediately (within 3 hours) to their local health department.

column1: What is coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)
column2: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a respiratory illness that can spread from person to person.

column1: How can I prevent COVID-19
column2: The best way to prevent illness is to avoid being exposed to the virus.

column1: Should I wear a face covering or face mask when I go out in public
column2: CDC recommends wearing cloth face coverings in public when other social distancing measures are difficult to maintain (e.g., grocery stores and pharmacies) especially in areas of significant community-based transmission of the coronavirus.

column1: What treatments are available for COVID-19
column2: People with COVID-19 should receive supportive care to help relieve symptoms. People with mild symptoms are able to recover at home.

column1: Can disinfectant sprays or wipes be used on my skin, injected, inhaled, or ingested to prevent or treat COVID-19
column2: No. Always follow the instructions on household cleaners. Disinfectant sprays or wipes are intended for use on hard, non-porous surfaces. Disinfectant sprays or wipes are not intended for use on humans or animals. Do not use disinfectant sprays or wipes on your skin because they may cause skin and eye irritation. Do not inject, inhale, or ingest disinfectant sprays or household cleaners; doing so is dangerous and may cause serious harm or death. If ingested, call poison control or a medical professional immediately.

column1: Where can I buy hand sanitizer
column2: Many retail stores and pharmacies sell hand sanitizers.

column1: If I can't find it in the store, can I make my own
column2: The FDA does not recommend that consumers make their own hand sanitizer.

column1: What do I do if I get a rash or other reaction to hand sanitizer
column2: Call your doctor if you experience a serious reaction to hand sanitizer. FDA encourages consumers and health care professionals to report adverse events experienced with the use of hand sanitizers to the FDA¡¯s MedWatch Adverse Event Reporting program.

column1: Where can I report websites selling fraudulent medical products
column2: You can report websites selling fraudulent medical products to the FDA through our website, by phone, or mail.

column1: Am I at risk for serious complications from COVID-19 if I smoke cigarettes
column2: Smoking cigarettes can leave you more vulnerable to respiratory illnesses such as COVID-19. Smoking cigarettes is known to cause heart and lung disease and people with underlying heart and lung problems may have increased risk for serious complications from COVID-19.

column1: If I vape tobacco or nicotine am I at risk for complications from COVID-19
column2: E-cigarette use can expose the lungs to toxic chemicals, but whether those exposures increase the risk of COVID-19 or the severity of COVID-19 outcomes is not known.

column1: What is a biological medical product or a biologic
column2: Biological products include a wide range of products such as vaccines, blood and blood components, allergenics, somatic cells, gene therapy, tissues, and recombinant therapeutic proteins. Biologics can be composed of sugars, proteins, or nucleic acids or complex combinations of these substances, or may be living entities such as cells and tissues.

column1: Are there any vaccines or other medical products to prevent COVID-19
column2: At this time there is no vaccine to prevent coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).

column1: Does COVID-19 present a risk to the safety of the nation¡¯s blood supply
column2: In general, respiratory viruses are not known to be transmitted by blood transfusion, and there have been no reported cases of transfusion-transmitted coronavirus.

column1: What steps are being taken to protect the U.S. blood supply from SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19
column2: Blood donors must be healthy and feel well on the day of donation. Routine blood donor screening measures that are already in place should prevent individuals with respiratory infections from donating blood.

column1: Why aren¡¯t blood centers testing donors for SARS-CoV-2
column2: Someone who has symptoms of COVID-19, including fever, cough, and shortness of breath, is not healthy enough to donate blood. Standard screening processes already in place will mean that someone with these symptoms will not be allowed to donate.

column1: Is it safe for me to donate blood during the coronavirus pandemic
column2: If you are healthy and interested in donating blood, the FDA encourages you to contact a local donation center to make an appointment.

column1: Can COVID-19 be transmitted through human cells, tissues, or cellular and tissue- based products (HCT/Ps)
column2: Respiratory viruses, in general, are not known to be transmitted by implantation, transplantation, infusion, or transfer of human cells, tissues, or cellular or tissue-based products (HCT/Ps).

column1: What is convalescent plasma
column2: Convalescent plasma is the liquid part of blood that is collected from patients who have recovered from the novel coronavirus disease, COVID-19, caused by the virus SARS-CoV-2.

column1: Why is convalescent plasma being investigated to treat COVID-19
column2: Convalescent plasma is being investigated for the treatment of COVID-19 because there is no approved treatment for this disease and there is some information that suggests it might help some patients recover from COVID-19.

column1: I recently recovered from COVID-19, can I donate convalescent plasma
column2: COVID-19 convalescent plasma must only be collected from recovered individuals if they are eligible to donate blood. Individuals must have had a prior diagnosis of COVID- 19 documented by a laboratory test and meet other laboratory criteria.

column1: Are there any FDA-approved drug products or medicines to treat COVID-19
column2: At this time, there are no FDA-approved drug products to treat COVID-19.

column1: Are antibiotics effective in preventing or treating COVID-19
column2: No. Antibiotics do not work against viruses; they only work on bacterial infections. Antibiotics do not prevent or treat coronavirus disease (COVID-19), because COVID-19 is caused by a virus, not bacteria.

column1: Will Miracle Mineral Solution (MMS) cure COVID-19
column2: No. Miracle Mineral Solution does not cure COVID-19 and has not been approved by the FDA for any use.

column1: Are chloroquine phosphate or hydroxychloroquine sulfate approved by the FDA to treat COVID-19
column2: No. Hydroxychloroquine sulfate and some versions of chloroquine phosphate are FDA-approved to treat malaria.

column1: May health care providers prescribe chloroquine phosphate or hydroxychloroquine sulfate off-label to treat patients with COVID-19
column2: Chloroquine phosphate is only approved for the treatment of malaria, and hydroxychloroquine sulfate is only approved for the treatment of malaria, lupus, and rheumatoid arthritis.

column1: Are there data showing that chloroquine phosphate or hydroxychloroquine sulfate might benefit patients with COVID-19
column2: In the lab, these drugs have been shown to prevent the growth of the virus that causes COVID-19. There are a few reports of patients with COVID-19 who received these drugs and improved. Some are reports of groups of patients, all of whom received the drug. It is not known whether it was the drug that led to the improvement or whether there were other factors involved.

column1: Should I take ivermectin to prevent or treat COVID-19
column2: No. While there are approved uses for ivermectin in people and animals, it is not approved for the prevention or treatment of COVID-19.

column1: What is the FDA doing to protect people from fraudulent COVID-19 products
column2: We have established a cross-agency task force dedicated to closely monitoring for fraudulent COVID-19 products.

column1: Are there going to be drug shortages due to drug manufacturer facility closures in China
column2: The FDA has been closely monitoring the supply chain with the expectation that the COVID-19 outbreak would likely impact the medical product supply chain, including potential disruptions to supply or shortages of critical medical products in the U.S.

column1: Am I at risk for COVID-19 from taking FDA-approved drugs made in China
column2: Currently, there is no evidence to support transmission of COVID-19 associated with imported goods, including food and drugs for humans and pets.

column1: Who should I contact with drug-related questions
column2: If you have additional questions, call FDA¡¯s Division of Drug Information at (855) 543-3784 or email us at druginfo@fda.hhs.gov (mailto:druginfo@fda.hhs.gov).

column1: Is there a test for COVID-19
column2: Yes, there are tests for COVID-19.

column1: How are people tested for COVID-19
column2: To be tested for COVID-19, a sample is typically collected from your nose and/or throat with a special swab at a designated collection location staffed by health care professionals.

column1: Are there any tests that I can purchase to test myself at home for COVID-19
column2: At this time, the FDA has not authorized any COVID-19 test to be completely used and processed at home.

column1: If antibody tests are not used for diagnosis or exclusion of SARS-CoV-2 infection, what is their purpose
column2: Antibody tests cannot be used alone to rule out COVID-19. However, they can serve an important role. Using antibody tests on many patients may help the medical community better understand the immune response in patients over time and how many people may have been infected.

column1: Should I purchase personal protective equipment such as facemasks or N95 respirators for me and my family
column2: No. Surgical masks and N95s need to be reserved for use by health care workers, first responders, and other frontline workers whose jobs put them at much greater risk of acquiring COVID-19.

column1: Is there a shortage of personal protective equipment (PPE) such as gloves, masks, and N95 respirators or of ventilators
column2: The agency is also aware of challenges throughout the supply chain that are presently impacting the availability of PPE products and is taking steps to mitigate shortages that health care facilities are already experiencing.

column1: Can 3D printing be used to make PPE
column2: While it is possible to use 3D printing to make certain PPE, there are technical challenges. 3D-printed PPE may provide a physical barrier, but 3D-printed PPE are unlikely to provide the same fluid barrier and air filtration protection as FDA-cleared surgical masks and N95 respirators

column1: Who should I contact if I have questions about medical devices or need more information
column2: Please contact the FDA¡¯s Center for Devices and Radiological Health (CDRH)¡¯s Division of Industry and Consumer Education (DICE) for general questions and information.

column1: Will there be food shortages
column2: There are no nationwide shortages of food, although in some cases the inventory of certain foods at your grocery store might be temporarily low before stores can restock.

column1: Will there be animal food shortages
column2: There are no nationwide shortages of animal food, although in some cases the inventory of certain foods at your grocery store might be temporarily low before stores can restock.

column1: What are the most important things I need to know to keep myself and others safe when I go to the grocery store during the pandemic
column2: There are steps you can take to help protect yourself, grocery store workers and other shoppers, such as wearing a face covering, practicing social distancing, and using wipes on the handles of the shopping cart or basket.

column1: Are food products produced in the United States or other countries affected by COVID- 19 a risk for the spread of COVID-19
column2: There is no evidence to suggest that food produced in the United States or imported from countries affected by COVID-19 can transmit COVID-19.

column1: Can I get the coronavirus from food, food packaging, or food containers and preparation area
column2: Currently there is no evidence of food, food containers, or food packaging being associated with transmission of COVID-19. Like other viruses, it is possible that the virus that causes COVID-19 can survive on surfaces or objects.

column1: Is the U.S. food supply safe
column2: Currently there is no evidence of food or food packaging being associated with transmission of COVID-19.

column1: Is the U.S. animal food supply safe
column2: Currently there is no evidence of animal food or food packaging being associated with transmission of COVID-19.

column1: Can I get COVID-19 from a food worker handling my food
column2: Currently, there is no evidence of food or food packaging being associated with transmission of COVID-19.

column1: Should food workers who are ill stay home
column2: CDC recommends that employees who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness stay home and not come to work until they are free of fever (100.4¡Æ F [37.8¡Æ C] or greater using an oral thermometer), signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours, without the use of fever-reducing or other symptom-altering medicines (e.g. cough suppressants).

column1: Should food facilities (grocery stores, manufacturing facilities, restaurants, etc.) perform any special cleaning or sanitation procedures for COVID-19
column2: CDC recommends routine cleaning of all frequently touched surfaces in the workplace, such as workstations, countertops, and doorknobs.

column1: Can I get COVID-19 from my pet or other animals
column2: There is currently no evidence that animals are a source of COVID-19 infection in the United States.

column1: Is there a test for COVID-19 in pets
column2: Certain veterinary diagnostic laboratories have developed diagnostic tests for SARS- CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, for use in pets if needed.

column1: Should I get my pet tested for COVID-19
column2: Routine testing of pets for COVID-19 is not recommended at this time.

column1: What animal species can get COVID-19
column2: We currently don¡¯t fully understand how COVID-19 affects different animal species. We are aware of a very small number of pets, including dogs and cats, reported to be infected with the virus that causes COVID-19 after close contact with people with COVID-19.

column1: Are there any approved products that can prevent or treat COVID-19 in animals
column2: No. Under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic (FD&C) Act, ¡°articles intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease in man or other animals¡± are drugs. The FDA has not approved any drugs for the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of COVID-19 in animals.

column1: Is it true that animals, like dogs, cats, and cattle, get their own different types of coronavirus
column2: Yes. Coronaviruses are a large family of viruses. Some coronaviruses like COVID-19 cause cold-like illnesses in people, while others cause illness in certain types of animals, such as cattle, camels, and bats. Some coronaviruses, such as canine and feline coronaviruses, only infect animals and do not infect humans.

column1: If my pet previously had a species-specific coronavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19
column2: There are no data to suggest that current or previous infection with another strain of coronavirus would make your pet more or less likely to get COVID-19.

column1: If my pet has been vaccinated for species-specific coronavirus, does that make them more or less likely to get COVID-19
column2: Species-specific coronavirus vaccines are unlikely to work against this type of coronavirus because it is a new virus that is different from the species-specific strains of coronavirus targeted by the vaccine.

column1: Is it safe to adopt pets from a shelter or rescue
column2: There is no reason to think that any animals, including shelter or rescue pets, in the United States, might be a source of COVID-19.

column1: Are there going to be any animal drug shortages due to the COVID-19 outbreak
column2: The FDA has been and is continuing to closely monitor how the COVID-19 outbreak may impact the animal medical product supply chain.

column1: When was the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus isolated first

column2: Most viruses don¡¯t spread easily on airplanes because of how the air circulates and is filtered.

column2: People who are immunocompromised are at higher risk from this illness, as well as other illnesses like the flu. Avoiding contact with ill people is crucial.

column2: A novel coronavirus is a new coronavirus that has not been previously identifed. The virus causing coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), is not the same as the coronaviruses that commonly circulate among humans and cause mild illness, like the common cold.

column2: The new name of this disease is coronavirus disease 2019, abbreviated as COVID-19. In COVID-19, ¡®CO¡¯ stands for ¡®corona,¡¯ ¡®VI¡¯ for ¡®virus,¡¯ and ¡®D¡¯ for disease. Formerly, this disease was referred to as ¡°2019 novel coronavirus¡± or ¡°2019-nCoV¡±.

column1: Why might someone blame or avoid individuals and groups (create stigma) because of COVID-19
column2: People in the U.S. may be worried or anxious about friends and relatives who are living in or visiting areas where COVID-19 is spreading. Some people are worried about getting the disease from these people. column1: How can people help stop stigma related to COVID-19
column2: People can fight stigma by providing social support in situations where you notice this is occurring.

column1: Why do some state¡¯s COVID-19 case numbers sometimes differ from what is posted on CDC¡¯s website
column2: CDC¡¯s overall case numbers are validated through a confirmation process with jurisdictions. The process used for finding and confirming cases displayed by different places may differ.

column1: How do CDC¡¯s COVID-19 case numbers compare with those provided by the World Health Organization (WHO) or Johns Hopkins
column2: CDC¡¯s COVID-19 case numbers include many publicly reported numbers, including information from state, local, territorial, international and external partners.

column1: Why do the number of cases for previous days increase
column2: Delays in reporting can cause the number of COVID-19 cases reported on previous days to increase.

column2: COVID-19 is caused by a coronavirus called SARS-CoV-2. column1: How does the virus spread
column2: The virus that causes COVID-19 is thought to spread mainly from person to person, mainly through respiratory droplets produced when an infected person coughs or sneezes.

column1: Why are we seeing a rise in cases
column2: The number of cases of COVID-19 being reported in the United States is rising due to increased laboratory testing and reporting across the country. The growing number of cases in part re$ects the rapid spread of COVID-19 as many U.S. states and territories experience community spread.

column2: Someone who has been released from COVID-19 quarantine is not considered a risk for spreading the virus to others because they have not developed illness during the incubation period.

column1: Can the virus that causes COVID-19 be spread through food, including restaurant take out, refrigerated or frozen packaged food

column1: Will warm weather stop the outbreak of COVID-19
column2: It is not yet known whether weather and temperature affect the spread of COVID-19.

column1: What is community spread

column1: Does CDC recommend the use of facemask or face coverings to prevent COVID-19

column2: Generally, well-controlled means that your condition is stable, not life-threatening, and laboratory assessments and other findings are as similar as possible to those without the health condition.
